No Political Life

One of the points most necessary
but difficult to understand -is that
there was virtually no political life
in China throughout the ages. China
was never an oriental despotism.
The system centering in the emperor worked through a system of
bureaucracy. The government has
been extremely democratic and
there has been no hereditary aristocracy. However, the business of
the government was apart from the
people, and those who did not take
an active part in the business of
governing in China had nothing to
do with it.
Dictatorship Established

When the Ancient Dynasty fell in
1911 no one outside of the small
group of officials had any conception of government. The bulk of
the people had remained outside of
the government, asking from it in
return for the payment of taxes
only a protection from bandits. The
local units took care of everything
we do in this country by state action. At the fall of the Manchu
government the most difficult form
of government, that of republic,
Which requires the sympathy and
approval of the people, was attempted. However, it developed
into a distatorship under Yuan
Shih-Kai, who was called the president but was, in fact, more dictatorial than the past emperors had been.

Moody Was Harvard Grad

William Vaughn Moody was born
in Indiana, in 1869. He was a graduate from Harvard. He taught in
New York and at Harvard, traveled
in Europe and finally settled down
in Chicago as a member of the English faculty at the University of
Chicago. He soon became known as
a popular teacher and his scholarly
work attracted attention. His real
recognition, however, came with the
publication of his first volume of
poems in 1902, which established
him among the foremost of American poets. In the same year he
gave up his teaching position so that
he might devote himself entirely to
writing. His most successful play,
"The Great Divide," was produced
in 1906 with Henry Miller and Margaret Anglin in the cast. He died at
Colorado Springs in October, 1910.
In its revival of "The Faith
Healer," The Playshop is following
the policy of presenting plays for
students as well as lovers of American drama. Moody's play is representative of the better drama to
be seen in the American theater at
the end of the first decade of this
century.

Time of Play 1789

The rising of the curtain discloses
the dimly lit interior of the "Black
Flamingo." It is the night of July
15, 1789, the night after the fall
of the Bastille. The nobles of the
regime are fleeing post-haste from
Paris. But they have been delayed,
while they gathered their jewelry.
This offered an opportunity for the
many thieves who infested Paris, to
leave the town, and prepare to waylay the refugees.
As the play opens, mysterious
wailing noises are heard in the inn,
which bother and torture the innkeeper, Felipe Bodier, a former
Parisian thief, his wife and their
maid Clotilde. Suddenly, there is a
knock at the door, and when it is
opened, one of Bodier's former
cronies enters. He brings news of
the turmoil in Paris, and of the
nobles' flight. Then, he and Bodier
prepare plans, in order to cope with
the situation, for they expect to loot
the effects of the exiles. At the
critical moment in their schemings,
a stranger appears, who warns them
of the coming of the nobles, with
tired horses. Bodier hurriedly prepares to receive his sudden guests.

a parade was suggested, and plans were laid for the affair amidst
the cheers of numerous undergraduates. Six days later a small but
noisy body of students gathered at the Barn and the parade started.
More students were picked up along the route, and a considerable
crowd was gathered at Baltimore and Charles Sts., where the parade
officially ended. Everything had run smoothly up to this point. A
large number of this group swamped the first bus that appeared in
order to return to the University. For no conceivable reason, about
ten of those on the bus immediately proceeded to break ic up as well
as they could. The bus that followed was also crowded with students,
but there was no general rough-house.
Can it be that this group has so little chance to show their school
spirit that such outbreaks naturally result? We doubt this. Any sane
student knows that such actions will result in the discontinuance of
parades, and any similar affairs in the future. Such outbursts merely
serve to show why nearly all such activities have been dropped at
Hopkins. Any student with real school spirit would not disgrace the
name of his school by exhibitions of this sort. Parades of a similar
nature in the past have not resulted in such occurrences. The blame
for the affair can be placed upon a small group of students who do
not have school spirit but rather a spirit of rowdyism, and a complete
Jack of respect for the rights and property of others. The majority
.of those on the bus took no part in the damaging of the vehicle.
If the breaking of the statue on Charles St. is found to be the work
of Hopkins students, some action may be expected from the Student
Council in the near future. This matter is of a much more serious
nature, as the damage done was considerably greater.

SPEAKING OF SPORTS
FOOTBALL
There could not have been a more
fitting close to the football season
than the game last Thursday. It
was typical of the Jay's work this
year. They were outweighed and
outplayed but never were they outfought. And most of the improvement of this year's team over the
eleven of 1929 can be traced to that
one important factor.
* * * *
The Jays won three games and
lost five this season for a percentage
of .375. While this is not an especially successful season if one
judge only by percentages, it will
be noticed that last year's percentage was only .125 and Haverford
and Swarthmore who won from the
Jays last year were defeated this
Year. Also the Lehigh and Maryland games this year showed that
Hopkins, while defeated, played a
much better brand of football than
the scores would indicate. It won't
be hard to convince people that
Hopkins grid teams are improving
and prospects for next year are indeed bright.
* * * *
This year the Jays scored 96
Points, while their opponents registered 131 against them. Coach Van
Orman's team scored more points
in their first two games than they
did against their opponents all last
season. Jack Turnbull led the Black
and Blue scorers with 58 points and
incidentally only Berger of Maryland and Koppe of Western Maryland topped him in the State scoring
race.
* * * *
And, in drawing the curtain on
the grid season we remove our hats:
To Captain Bialaskorski for his
stellar work on the line all season,
to "Otts" Helm for the same reason, to Jack Turnbull for his work
in the backfield, to Bobby Lyons for
his punting, to the entire team for
the exhibition they gave in the
Thanksgiving struggle with Maryland.

Dr. Randall epitomized the world
situation into a struggle between
"things of the past and things that
are to be." He stated that the
League of Nations in its conferences supplies an excellent barometer of world-feeling.
The 1929 session of the League
Was . pervaded with a spirit of
mutual confidence and trust between the 55 nations, represented
there, whereas the 1930 session was
characterized as being shrouded in
an impermeable fog of gloom and
pessimism.
Differences Account for Turmoil

"It is no wonder that all Western
Rurope is in a continual turmoil
and whispering rumors of war,"
declared Dr. Randall. The forces
contributing to this condition of
Political and economic unrest he
cited as being the violent disagreements between Jugo-Slavia and
Italy; the fight over naval parity
now being waged between France
and Italy; the fact that Hungary is
Planning to restore the Hapsburg
monarchy in spite of the threatenings of her neighbors to invade her
borders if she carries out her plan;
and the conditions that exist in
Germany and France favoring the
Nationalist movement and threatening the peace of these two countries
by questioning the agreements- contained in the Versailles Treaty.
Suspicion Due To Depression

Dr. Randall attributed the suspicion which existed in the last
League of Nations session to the
economic depression which exists
at the present time all over the
World, being accompanied by the
unemployment of 12,000,000 Europeans. An economic struggle is
Imminent and Dr. Randall directed
attention to Russia's vast strides as
Promising to be a prime factor in
world economic situations in the
future.

distrust and suspicion existing are

SPEAKING OF SPORTS
FOOTBALL
There could not have been a more
fitting close to the football season
than the game last Thursday. It
was typical of the Jay's work this
year. They were outweighed and
outplayed but never were they outfought. And most of the improvement of this year's team over the
eleven of 1929 can be traced to that
one important factor.
* * * *
The Jays won three games and
lost five this season for a percentage
of .375. While this is not an especially successful season if one
judge only by percentages, it will
be noticed that last year's percentage was only .125 and Haverford
and Swarthmore who won from the
Jays last year were defeated this
Year. Also the Lehigh and Maryland games this year showed that
Hopkins, while defeated, played a
much better brand of football than
the scores would indicate. It won't
be hard to convince people that
Hopkins grid teams are improving
and prospects for next year are indeed bright.
* * * *
This year the Jays scored 96
Points, while their opponents registered 131 against them. Coach Van
Orman's team scored more points
in their first two games than they
did against their opponents all last
season. Jack Turnbull led the Black
and Blue scorers with 58 points and
incidentally only Berger of Maryland and Koppe of Western Maryland topped him in the State scoring
race.
* * * *
And, in drawing the curtain on
the grid season we remove our hats:
To Captain Bialaskorski for his
stellar work on the line all season,
to "Otts" Helm for the same reason, to Jack Turnbull for his work
in the backfield, to Bobby Lyons for
his punting, to the entire team for
the exhibition they gave in the
Thanksgiving struggle with Maryland.
BASKETBALL
With the curtain falling on the
gridiron, we are reminded of the
advent of the basketball season.
Coach Darley has been working out
all this week with his cagers and
Prospects are promising.
Artie Siegel, Fritz Stude- and
Johnny Heizerling are back and
this trio will form the nucleus of
this year's quint. In addition, there
Will be reserves from last year, to
say nothing of numerous Freshmen who starred at their respective
high schools. We repeat that the
Prospects for a successful season
are bright.
* * * *
With the opening game only a bit
over two weeks distant, Coach Darley is whipping his proteges into
Shape. On Tuesday a short period
of passing and goal-tossing was followed by a stiff scrimmage, every
man present being given a chalice to
Play. Rough spots in passing and
Shooting were, of course, evident,
but with the material on hand and
that which may be not-too-optimistically expected, the team has more
than mere possibilities.
